Week 9 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • Functions

  • Inverses

    • What is an Inverse?

  • Inverse Trigonometric Functions

  • Integration by Parts

Functions

A function fff always comes with a domain DDD, and the range of fff is determined by DDD. If the domain isn't specified, then it's usually taken to be the largest set where fff is defined.

Example 1.

If f(x)=1xf\p{x} = \frac{1}{x}f(x)=x1​ and DDD is not specified, then we assume D={x∈R∣x≠0}D = \set{x \in \R \mid x \neq 0}D={x∈R∣x=0}.
Example 2.

Let f(x)=x2f\p{x} = x^2f(x)=x2.

  • D=R  ⟹  R=[0,∞)D = \R \implies R = \left[ 0, \infty \right)D=R⟹R=[0,∞)

  • D=[0,∞)  ⟹  R=[0,∞)D = \left[ 0, \infty \right) \implies R = \left[ 0, \infty \right)D=[0,∞)⟹R=[0,∞)

  • D={x∈R∣x>2}  ⟹  R=(4,∞)D = \set{x \in \R \mid x > 2} \implies R = \p{4, \infty}D={x∈R∣x>2}⟹R=(4,∞)

Inverses

What is an Inverse?

Given a function fff, we'd like to know if we can go "backwards" from fff. This is useful if you need to solve something like f(x)=yf\p{x} = yf(x)=y; if we can "undo" fff, then we automatically have the solution to the equation. This can be done if fff is invertible:

Definition

Let fff have domain DDD and range RRR. If ∃g\exists g∃g with domain RRR and range DDD such that

  • f(g(x))=xf\p{g\p{x}} = xf(g(x))=x for all x∈Rx \in Rx∈R and
  • g(f(x))=xg\p{f\p{x}} = xg(f(x))=x for all x∈Dx \in Dx∈D,

then we say fff is invertible and we call f−1=gf^{-1} = gf−1=g the inverse of fff.

When is there an Inverse?

So when does fff have an inverse? Let's look at a situation where fff does not have one.

fff doesn't have an inverse here because we can't go backwards from yyy to get both aaa and bbb. Indeed, any function ggg with domain RRR will map yyy to either aaa or bbb, but not both. The problem is that fff maps two different elements to the same thing, so if we prevent this, fff will have an inverse.

To prevent this, we need fff to map two different elements to two different things. More succinctly, a≠b  ⟹  f(a)≠f(b)a \neq b \implies f\p{a} \neq f\p{b}a=b⟹f(a)=f(b). If fff satisfies this, then we call fff one-to-one, but this isn't the only way to tell if fff is one-to-one:

Definition (one-to-one)

Let fff have domain DDD, and suppose one of the following is true about fff:

  • a≠b  ⟹  f(a)≠f(b)a \neq b \implies f\p{a} \neq f\p{b}a=b⟹f(a)=f(b) for any a,b∈Da, b \in Da,b∈D or
  • f(x)=yf\p{x} = yf(x)=y has exactly one solution for every y∈Ry \in Ry∈R or
  • f(a)=f(b)  ⟹  a=bf\p{a} = f\p{b} \implies a = bf(a)=f(b)⟹a=b for any a,b∈Da, b \in Da,b∈D or
  • fff passes the horizontal line test.

Then we say fff is one-to-one or injective.

Notice that the domain is very important when determining whether fff is one-to-one or not.

Example 3.

Let f(x)=x2f\p{x} = x^2f(x)=x2.

  • If D=RD = \RD=R, then fff is not one-to-one.

    f(x)=1f\p{x} = 1f(x)=1 has two solutions: −1-1−1 and 111.

  • If D=[0,∞)D = \left[ 0, \infty \right)D=[0,∞), then fff is one-to-one.

    Since fff is one-to-one, it has an inverse, which is f−1(x)=xf^{-1}\p{x} = \sqrt{x}f−1(x)=x​.

Inverse Trigonometric Functions

Definitions

In order to define inverse trig functions, we need to find domains so that they are one-to-one without changing their ranges. Because trig functions oscillate, there are a lot of intervals like these, so which one do we take? 000 is a nice number, so we are going to look for a domain containing 000 which doesn't change the range of our function.

Take a look at the graph of sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx:

As you can see, [−π2,π2]\br{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}}[−2π​,2π​] does the trick. On this interval, sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx passes the horizontal line test and it hits every point in its range, [−1,1]\br{-1, 1}[−1,1].

Now look at cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx:

There are two intervals in this case: [−π,0]\br{-\pi, 0}[−π,0] and [0,π]\br{0, \pi}[0,π]. Hopefully, you agree that [0,π]\br{0, \pi}[0,π] is "nicer" than the other one since it contains only positive numbers, so we're going to restrict cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx to [0,π]\br{0, \pi}[0,π] when defining the inverse.

The last one we're going to look at is tan⁡x\tan{x}tanx:

As in the case with cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx, we have multiple choices, but I think it's clear that (−π2,π2)\p{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}}(−2π​,2π​) is the "nicest" interval we can use.

We can play the same game with the rest of the trig functions, and what we get are the following inverse functions:

Definition (inverse trigonometric functions)

We define the inverses of trig functions via the following tables:

f(x)f−1(x)rangesin⁡xarcsin⁡x[−π2,π2]csc⁡xarccsc⁡x[−π2,0)∪(0,π2]tan⁡xarctan⁡x(−π2,π2)\def\arraystretch{1.5} \begin{array}{lll} f\p{x} & f^{-1}\p{x} & \text{range} \\ \hline \sin{x} & \arcsin{x} & \br{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}} \\ \csc{x} & \arccsc{x} & \left\lbrack -\frac{\pi}{2}, 0 \right\rparen \cup \left\lparen 0, \frac{\pi}{2} \right\rbrack \\ \tan{x} & \arctan{x} & \p{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}} \end{array}f(x)sinxcscxtanx​f−1(x)arcsinxarccscxarctanx​range[−2π​,2π​][−2π​,0)∪(0,2π​](−2π​,2π​)​​
f(x)f−1(x)rangecos⁡xarccos⁡x[0,π]sec⁡xarcsec⁡x[0,π2)∪(π2,π]cot⁡xarccot⁡x(0,π)\def\arraystretch{1.5} \begin{array}{lll} f\p{x} & f^{-1}\p{x} & \text{range} \\ \hline \cos{x} & \arccos{x} & \br{0, \pi} \\ \sec{x} & \arcsec{x} & \left\lbrack 0, \frac{\pi}{2} \right\rparen \cup \left\lparen \frac{\pi}{2}, \pi \right\rbrack \\ \cot{x} & \arccot{x} & \p{0, \pi} \end{array}f(x)cosxsecxcotx​f−1(x)arccosxarcsecxarccotx​range[0,π][0,2π​)∪(2π​,π](0,π)​​

We get the range of f−1(x)f^{-1}\p{x}f−1(x) by swapping the domain and range of f(x)f\p{x}f(x).

Exercise 1.

Figure out the domains of the inverse trig functions.

One thing to notice is how I arranged the tables. If you look at the top table, the ranges are all [−π2,π2]\br{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}}[−2π​,2π​] with some points removed, i.e., the range of arcsin⁡x\arcsin{x}arcsinx with some points removed. Similarly, the bottom table ranges are all the range of arccos⁡x\arccos{x}arccosx with some points removed.

The way I remember how to group them are as follows: if sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx is the "main" function (e.g., csc⁡x=1sin⁡x\csc{x} = \frac{1}{\sin{x}}cscx=sinx1​), then the range is related to arcsin⁡x\arcsin{x}arcsinx. Similarly, if cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx is the "main" function, then the range will be related to arccos⁡x\arccos{x}arccosx.

Derivatives

Now that we have the inverses, let's talk about their derivatives:

Theorem
ddxarcsin⁡x=−11−x2ddxarccos⁡x=−11−x2ddxarctan⁡x=−11+x2ddxarcsec⁡x=−1∣x∣x2−1ddxarccsc⁡x=−1∣x∣x2−1ddxarccot⁡x=−11+x2\begin{aligned} &\deriv{}{x} \arcsin{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arccos{x} &=& -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arctan{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arcsec{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arccsc{x} &=& -\frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arccot{x} &=& -\frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ \end{aligned}​dxd​arcsinxdxd​arccosxdxd​arctanxdxd​arcsecxdxd​arccscxdxd​arccotx​======​−1−x2​1​−1−x2​1​−1+x21​−∣x∣x2−1​1​−∣x∣x2−1​1​−1+x21​​

These are all done by implicit differentiation, and I'll show one of them:

Example 4.

Prove that ddxarcsec⁡x=1∣x∣x2−1\deriv{}{x} \arcsec{x} = \frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}dxd​arcsecx=∣x∣x2−1​1​.
Solution.

To start, I'm going to set y=arcsec⁡xy = \arcsec{x}y=arcsecx. Since arcsec⁡x\arcsec{x}arcsecx and sec⁡x\sec{x}secx are inverses, we can apply sec⁡θ\sec{\theta}secθ to both sides to get sec⁡y=x\sec{y} = xsecy=x. Now we can take derivatives on both sides to get

(sec⁡ytan⁡y)y′=1  ⟹  y′=1sec⁡ytan⁡y.\p{\sec{y}\tan{y}} y' = 1 \implies y' = \frac{1}{\sec{y}\tan{y}}.(secytany)y′=1⟹y′=secytany1​.

To finish the problem, we need to get the right-hand side in terms of xxx. We already know that sec⁡y=x\sec{y} = xsecy=x, so we need to handle tan⁡y\tan{y}tany. We can use the following trig identity to relate tan⁡y\tan{y}tany to sec⁡y=x\sec{y} = xsecy=x:

tan⁡2y+1=sec⁡2y=x2  ⟹  tan⁡2y=x2−1  ⟹  tan⁡y=±x2−1.\begin{aligned} \tan^2{y} + 1 = \sec^2{y} = x^2 &\implies \tan^2{y} = x^2 - 1 \\ &\implies \tan{y} = \pm\sqrt{x^2 - 1}. \end{aligned}tan2y+1=sec2y=x2​⟹tan2y=x2−1⟹tany=±x2−1​.​

We need to figure out when the sign is positive and when the sign is negative, so we need to break it into two cases:

Case 1: sec⁡y=x>0\sec{y} = x > 0secy=x>0

Since y=arcsec⁡xy = \arcsec{x}y=arcsecx, yyy is in the range of arcsec⁡x\arcsec{x}arcsecx, so yyy is in the first or second quadrant.

Since sec⁡y>0\sec{y} > 0secy>0, this means that cos⁡y>0\cos{y} > 0cosy>0, which means that yyy must be in Quadrant I. In this quadrant, tan⁡y>0\tan{y} > 0tany>0, so tan⁡y=x2−1\tan{y} = \sqrt{x^2 - 1}tany=x2−1​ in this case.

Case 2: sec⁡y=x<0\sec{y} = x < 0secy=x<0

We can use the same argument: in this case, cos⁡y<0\cos{y} < 0cosy<0, so yyy is in Quadrant II, which means that tan⁡y<0\tan{y} < 0tany<0. Thus, tan⁡y=−x2−1\tan{y} = -\sqrt{x^2 - 1}tany=−x2−1​ in this case.

Now that we have established the signs of tan⁡y\tan{y}tany, we just need to plug it back into our original function. There are two cases, so we end up with a piecewise function:

y′=1xtan⁡y={1−xx2−1if x>01−xx2−1if x<0=1∣x∣x2−1.\begin{aligned} y' &= \frac{1}{x\tan{y}} \\ &= \begin{cases} \dfrac{1}{\phantom{-}x\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} & \text{if } x > 0 \\[2ex] \dfrac{1}{-x\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} & \text{if } x < 0 \end{cases} \\ &= \frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}. \end{aligned}y′​=xtany1​=⎩⎨⎧​−xx2−1​1​−xx2−1​1​​if x>0if x<0​=∣x∣x2−1​1​.​

The last equality comes from the fact that ∣x∣=x\abs{x} = x∣x∣=x if x>0x > 0x>0 and −x-x−x if x<0x < 0x<0.

Integration by Parts

Theorem (integration by parts)

If uuu and vvv are functions, then

∫u dv=uv−∫v du.\int u \,\diff{v} = uv - \int v \,\diff{u}.∫udv=uv−∫vdu.

Given an integral, you're free to choose uuu and dv\diff{v}dv however you like. However, the main issue after applying the formula is the integral term ∫v du\int v \,\diff{u}∫vdu, so before you start, try to think about what v duv \,\diff{u}vdu looks like.

The way I remember the formula is that you pick one thing to differentiate (uuu) and one thing to integrate (dv\diff{v}dv). Then you integrate first to get uvuvuv and then differentiate after to get v duv \,\diff{u}vdu.

Examples

Example 5.

Calculate ∫xsin⁡x dx\displaystyle \int x\sin{x} \,\diff{x}∫xsinxdx.
Solution.

For this problem, you'll want to differentiate xxx because it will just become 111. If you integrate x dxx \,\diff{x}xdx, then you end up with 12x2\frac{1}{2} x^221​x2, which is more complicated. So, we'll use u=xu = xu=x and dv=sin⁡x dx\diff{v} = \sin{x} \,\diff{x}dv=sinxdx, which gives us

du=dxandv=−cos⁡x.\diff{u} = \diff{x} \quad\text{and}\quad v = -\cos{x}.du=dxandv=−cosx.

Thus,

∫xsin⁡x dx=−xcos⁡x−∫−cos⁡x dx=−xcos⁡x+∫cos⁡x dx=−xcos⁡x+sin⁡x+C.\begin{aligned} \int x\sin{x} \,\diff{x} &= -x\cos{x} - \int -\cos{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= -x\cos{x} + \int \cos{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \boxed{-x\cos{x} + \sin{x} + C}. \end{aligned}∫xsinxdx​=−xcosx−∫−cosxdx=−xcosx+∫cosxdx=−xcosx+sinx+C​.​
Example 6.

Calculate ∫cos⁡−1x dx\displaystyle \int \cos^{-1}{x} \,\diff{x}∫cos−1xdx.
Solution.

Even though there's only one term, we can still use integration by parts because cos⁡−1x=cos⁡−1x⋅1\cos^{-1}{x} = \cos^{-1}{x} \cdot 1cos−1x=cos−1x⋅1. Choose dv=cos⁡−1x dx\diff{v} = \cos^{-1}{x} \,\diff{x}dv=cos−1xdx isn't going to do anything for us because we don't know how to integrate it (yet), so we need to let u=cos⁡−1xu = \cos^{-1}{x}u=cos−1x and dv=dx\diff{v} = \diff{x}dv=dx instead. Then

du=−dx1−x2andv=x.\diff{u} = -\frac{\diff{x}}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \quad\text{and}\quad v = x.du=−1−x2​dx​andv=x.

So if we integrate by parts, we get

∫cos⁡−1x dx=xcos⁡−1x−∫−x1−x2 dx=xcos⁡−1x+∫x1−x2 dx=xcos⁡−1x−1−x2+C.\begin{aligned} \int \cos^{-1}{x} \,\diff{x} &= x\cos^{-1}{x} - \int -\frac{x}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= x\cos^{-1}{x} + \int \frac{x}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \boxed{x\cos^{-1}{x} - \sqrt{1 - x^2} + C}. \end{aligned}∫cos−1xdx​=xcos−1x−∫−1−x2​x​dx=xcos−1x+∫1−x2​x​dx=xcos−1x−1−x2​+C​.​

(To calculate the integral, you can use u=1−x2u = 1 - x^2u=1−x2.)
Example 7.

Calculate ∫ln⁡x dx\displaystyle \int \ln{x} \,\diff{x}∫lnxdx.
Solution.

Like the example before, we can let u=ln⁡xu = \ln{x}u=lnx and dv=dx\diff{v} = \diff{x}dv=dx. Then

du=dxxandv=x,\diff{u} = \frac{\diff{x}}{x} \quad\text{and}\quad v = x,du=xdx​andv=x,

so we get

∫ln⁡x dx=xln⁡x−∫x⋅1x dx=xln⁡x−∫ dx=xln⁡x−x+C.\begin{aligned} \int \ln{x} \,\diff{x} &= x\ln{x} - \int x \cdot \frac{1}{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &= x\ln{x} - \int \,\diff{x} \\ &= \boxed{x\ln{x} - x + C}. \end{aligned}∫lnxdx​=xlnx−∫x⋅x1​dx=xlnx−∫dx=xlnx−x+C​.​
Example 8.

Calculate ∫ln⁡xx3 dx\displaystyle \int \frac{\ln{x}}{x^3} \,\diff{x}∫x3lnx​dx.
Solution.

I want to differentiate ln⁡x\ln{x}lnx because it gives me 1x\frac{1}{x}x1​, which plays nicely with all the other terms. So, we want to choose u=ln⁡xu = \ln{x}u=lnx and dv=1x3 dx\diff{v} = \frac{1}{x^3} \,\diff{x}dv=x31​dx, which gives

du=dxxandv=−12x2.\diff{u} = \frac{\diff{x}}{x} \quad\text{and}\quad v = -\frac{1}{2x^2}.du=xdx​andv=−2x21​.

Then the integral becomes

∫ln⁡xx3 dx=−ln⁡x2x2−∫−dx2x3=−ln⁡x2x2+∫dx2x3=−ln⁡x2x2−14x2+C=−(2ln⁡x−14x2)+C.\begin{aligned} \int \frac{\ln{x}}{x^3} \,\diff{x} &= -\frac{\ln{x}}{2x^2} - \int -\frac{\diff{x}}{2x^3} \\ &= -\frac{\ln{x}}{2x^2} + \int \frac{\diff{x}}{2x^3} \\ &= -\frac{\ln{x}}{2x^2} - \frac{1}{4x^2} + C \\ &= \boxed{-\p{\frac{2\ln{x} - 1}{4x^2}} + C}. \end{aligned}∫x3lnx​dx​=−2x2lnx​−∫−2x3dx​=−2x2lnx​+∫2x3dx​=−2x2lnx​−4x21​+C=−(4x22lnx−1​)+C​.​
